The illustration to the left depicts a basic foundation drain system. This type of drainage systems are included at the foundation level of basement homes, retaining walls, and similiar below grade applications. This is critical for basements to prevent hydrostatic pressure from building up alongside the foundation walls.
Improperly installed or damaged drains may result in water leakage or dampness in the basement or crawl space area.

There is little maintenance invovled with this item. An annual inspection should be made to verify that the ends of the drain have positive slope away from the foundation and that there is
no obstruction inside the pipe.
Caution should be used when planting shrubs or other landscaping near your foundation that could damage or hinder the workings of the drain. Roots from plants or small trees can sometimes block or crush the system making it ineffective.

In a proper installation you will observe that the piping extends at foundation level to the lowest point of grade. Notice in the illustration provided that one end is lower than the other, indicating proper pitch. Never bury the ends of a foundation drain. If you cannot see the foundation drain system and are experiencing water issues or dampness you should contact your builder or a foundation & waterproofing specialist.
